title: Carved Wooden Pawukon Calendar with Lime Highlights
content:
accession_no_csv: 2017-00615

  Image: 

  object_work_type: carvings (visual works) calendars (documents by form)

  title_text: Carved Wooden Pawukon Calendar with Lime Highlights

  preference: main

  title_language: 

  creation_date: Early 20th Century

  creation_place_original_location: Bali (Indonesia : Province)

  styles_periods_indexing_terms: Balinese

  inscriptions: 

  inscription_language: 

  shape: irregular

  materials_name: wood (plant material) calcium hydroxide

  techniques_name: woodcarving

  object_colour: dark brown

  physical_appearance: This is a wood carving of a Balinese calendar. It is carved with a loop on an elongated neck on the left. Along the bottom
 there is a single row of drilled holes. The face of the plank is engraved with 210 squares. The squares are marked with a series of crosses and circles
 with some marked with a small stud. The edges of the engraving are whitened and highlighted. The calendar looks slightly worn out.

  subject_terms_1: Balinese ways of life customs (social concepts)

  subject_terms_2: Wood-carving Calendars Balinese (Indonesian people) Lifestyles Manners and customs

  subject_terms_3: Heritage and Culture

  subject_terms_4: 

  sgcool_label_text: Calendars were used on Bali and Lombok to determine the correct time for festivals
 rituals associated with rice planting
 and horoscopes. Calendars were either painted on cotton cloth
 or carved from wooden boards as with the example here. \r\nThe front of this board is entirely engraved with 210 squares (seven days by thirty weeks - this being a full year in the Balinese Pawukon calendar of 210 days) and these are marked with a series of crosses and circles. Some of the squares are also marked with small metal studs. The reverse is engraved with 35 squares (seven days by five weeks for the Balinese/Lombok month of 35 days). The engraving is highlighted with lime powder which has been rubbed into the depressions.

metadata.title_text: Carved Wooden Pawukon Calendar with Lime Highlights
metadata.physical_appearance: This is a wood carving of a Balinese calendar. It is carved with a loop on an elongated neck on the left. Along the bottom, there is a single row of drilled holes. The face of the plank is engraved with 210 squares. The squares are marked with a series of crosses and circles, with some marked with a small stud. The edges of the engraving are whitened and highlighted. The calendar looks slightly worn out.
metadata.subject_terms_1: Balinese ways of life customs (social concepts)
metadata.subject_terms_2: Wood-carving Calendars Balinese (Indonesian people) Lifestyles Manners and customs
metadata.sgcool_label_text:
Calendars were used on Bali and Lombok to determine the correct time for festivals, rituals associated with rice planting, and horoscopes. Calendars were either painted on cotton cloth, or carved from wooden boards as with the example here. 
The front of this board is entirely engraved with 210 squares (seven days by thirty weeks - this being a full year in the Balinese Pawukon calendar of 210 days) and these are marked with a series of crosses and circles. Some of the squares are also marked with small metal studs. The reverse is engraved with 35 squares (seven days by five weeks for the Balinese/Lombok month of 35 days). The engraving is highlighted with lime powder which has been rubbed into the depressions.
